Definition: Given a tuple, comprising Head and Tail, separated with <sep>, you have to determine whether, as a result of the Head, PersonY, or others, feel what is mentioned in the Tail or not. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No".
Domains: Commonsense -> Concepts and Relations -> Social Commonsense

Positive Examples.input: Head: PersonX adapts ___ to conditions<sep>Tail: Get things done more effectively
Positive Examples.explanation: As a result of the Head, The others won't feel things are done more effectively.

Positive Examples.input: Head: PersonX lights ___ on fire<sep>Tail: none
Positive Examples.explanation: This is a good example. As a result of Head sentence, others will feel nothing.

Positive Examples.input: Head: PersonX asks PersonY to play<sep>Tail: to play
Positive Examples.explanation: In this example, "to play" is not an emotional reaction. Thus, this example should be classified as "No".

Negative Examples.input: Head: PersonX affects children 's ___<sep>Tail: to make a difference
Negative Examples.explanation: If PersonX affects children 's ___, others won't feel to make a difference. So the output should be "No".

Negative Examples.input: Head: PersonX gives PersonY command<sep>Tail: like they are set to task
Negative Examples.explanation: If PersonX gives PersonY command, PersonY will feel like he/she is set to the task, and the output should be "Yes".

Instances.input: Head: PersonX asks PersonX's grandma<sep>Tail: to pick up their grandma
Head: PersonX goes camping during the weekend<sep>Tail: also happy
Head: PersonX adjusts spacing as well as minimizing<sep>Tail: WOEKING TO ALL
